prompt.content:
You are a system that generates high quality document role annotations based on Framenet ontology.
The following inputs are given to you:
1. Event Type <event_type>: A Frame name from the FrameNet ontology (eg: Hiring, Arrest, etc.)
2. Event Definition <event_definition>: Definition of the event type along with an optional example. 
3. Roles <event_roles>: All roles (or participants) of the event type (or frame) followed with an optional example.
4. Report Document <report_document>: A report document with a tagged event '<event>' of the given event type.

Your job is to extract all the roles of the tagged Report <event> from the <report_document>. The ouput should be in a JSON string
where each key represents the role name as provided in the <event_roles> and its corresponding value should be a
list of contiguous text spans from the <report_document> that are valid for that role. 
Note that if no text span is found for a role, the value should be an empty list. 
Your text spans should strictly come from the <report_document>. DO NOT use spans from Event Definition or Roles sections.

<event_type> Hiring </event_type>         <event_definition> An Employer hires an Employee, promising the Employee a certain Compensation in exchange for the performance of a job. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Employee: The person whom the <fen>Employer</fen> takes on as an <fen>Employee</fen>, obligating them to perform some <fen>Task</fen> in order to receive <fen>Compensation</fen>.
<fex>I</fex> was just hired yesterday!
2. Employer: The person (or institution) that takes on an <fen>Employee</fen>, giving them  <fen>Compensation</fen> in return for the performance of an assigned <fen>Task</fen>.
Last month, <fex>IBM</fex> hired Mike Zisman to head up its storage software group.
3. Task: The action that the <fen>Employee</fen> is taken on by the <fen>Employer</fen> to do.
I was hired <fex>just to empty the trash cans</fex>.
4. Position: The label given to a particular type of employment.
Look, I wasn't hired <fex>as your waitress</fex>!
5. Field: The <fen>Field</fen> that the <fen>Employee</fen> is going to work in for their <fen>Employer</fen>.
It's not easy to get hired <fex>in academia</fex>.
6. Time: This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Guess who just got hired <fex>today</fex>!
7. Place: This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Actually, he hired me <fex>in a bordello</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> He was <event> hired </event> as a Research Scientist by Microsoft. </report_document>

{
  "Employee": ["He"],
  "Employer": ["Microsoft"],
  "Task": [],
  "Position": ["as a Research Scientist"],
  "Field": []
}

<event_type> Clemency </event_type>         <event_definition> An Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an Offender who participated in an Crime. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Offender: The individual who is accused or convicted of a <fen>Crime</fen>.
Since 1976, <fex>225 death row inmates</fex> have been granted clemency for humanitarian
reasons. 
2. Crime: An action deemed criminal by law.
I never saw a legal case where a person was given clemency <fex>for murder</fex>.
3. Executive_authority: The constitutionally specified authority who has the power to grant clemency.
Mr. Papa was granted clemency for a drug conviction <fex>by Mr. Pataki</fex>, and released in 1997
4. Time: The time at which clemency is granted.
In addition to Ms.  White, 55, Mr.  Pataki granted clemency <fex>yesterday</fex> to three men serving long prison terms for offenses under the stern Rockefeller-era drug laws that mandate long sentences for some relatively low-level drug crimes.
5. Place: The location at which the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> grants clemency.
Apparently, no woman has ever been granted clemency <fex>there</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> In 2023, the governor granted <event> clemency </event> to the prisoner who had been wrongly convicted. </report_document>

{
  "Offender": ["the prisoner"],
  "Crime": [],
  "Executive_authority": ["The governor"],
  "Time": ["2023"],
  "Place": []
}

<event_type> Abandonment </event_type>         <event_definition> An Agent leaves behind a Theme effectively rendering it no longer within their control or of the normal security as one's property. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Agent: The <fex name='Agent'>Agent</fex> is the person who acts to leave behind the <fen>Theme</fen>.

2. Theme: The <fex name='Theme'>Theme</fex> is the entity that is relinguished to no one from the <fex name='Agent'>Agent</fex>'s possession.

3. Time: When the <fen>Agent</fen> gives up the <fen>Theme</fen>.

4. Place: The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> gives up the <fen>Theme</fen>.

 </event_roles>        <report_document> Several parts of the bill , including the proposed register for home educators , and compulsory sex education lessons , were <event> abandoned </event> as they had failed to gain cross party support prior to the pending May 2010 election . </report_document>

<event_type> Clemency </event_type>         <event_definition> An Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an Offender who participated in an Crime. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Offender: The individual who is accused or convicted of a <fen>Crime</fen>.
Since 1976, <fex>225 death row inmates</fex> have been granted clemency for humanitarian
reasons. 
2. Crime: An action deemed criminal by law.

5. Place: The location at which the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> grants clemency.

{

  "Crime": [],
  "Executive_authority": ["The governor"],
  "Time": ["2023"],
  "Place": []
}

<event_type> Abusing </event_type>         <event_definition> In this frame an Abuser repeatedly treats the Victim in a cruel and violent way, including physically harming or forcing the Victim to engage in sexual activity against their will. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Abuser: The <fen>Abuser</fen> subjects the <fen>Victim</fen> to repeated verbal, physical, emotional or sexual attacks.
<fex>Fred</fex> abused Martha by locking her into a closet .
2. Victim: The <fen>Victim</fen> is the recipient of the <fen>Abuser</fen>'s actions.
Fred abused <fex>Martha</fex> by locking her into a closet .
3. Time: This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the abuse occurs.

4. Place: This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the abuse occurs.

 </event_roles>        <report_document> Subsequently , a number of women made allegations against Casey that they were sexually <event> abused </event> by him , two of which received compensation following a High Court trial . One of the women , his niece Patricia Donovan , alleged in 2019 that she was repeatedly raped by Casey when she was five years old and assaulted sexually by him for more than a decade . </report_document>

<event_type> Change_position_on_a_scale </event_type>         <event_definition> This frame consists of words that indicate the change of an Item's position on a scale (the Attribute) from a starting point (Initial_value) to an end point (Final_value). </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Attribute: The <fen>Attribute</fen> is a scalar property that the <fen>Item</fen> possesses.
Oil rose <fex>in price</fex> by 2%.
2. Item: The entity that has a position on the scale.
I fear <fex>this service</fex> will diminish in quality.
3. Difference: The distance by which an <fen>Item</fen> changes its position on the scale.
Oil rose in price <fex>by 2%</fex>.
4. Final_value: The position on the scale where the <fen>Item</fen> ends up.

5. Initial_value: The initial position on the scale from which the <fen>Item</fen> moves away.

6. Value_range: A portion of the scale, typically identified by its end points, along which the values of the <fen>Attribute</fen> fluctuate.

7. Initial_state: A description that presents the <fen>Item</fen>'s state before the change in the <fen>Attribute</fen>'s value as an independent predication.

It was never bad (1 or 2 seizures a year), but this past decade, it has increased
<fex>to having them 1 day a month</fex> and on that 1 day I have 6 or 7 seizures.
9. Time: The <fen>Time</fen> is the time-frame in which the change of position occurs.

10. Place: A location where Attribute is measured

1. Event Type <event_type>: A Frame name from the FrameNet ontology (eg: Hiring, Arrest, etc.)
2. Event Definition <event_definition>: Definition of the event type along with an optional example. 
3. Roles <event_roles>: All roles (or participants) of the event type (or frame) followed with an optional example.
4. Report Document <report_document>: A report document with a tagged event '<event>' of the given event type.

Your job is to extract all the roles of the tagged Report <event> from the <report_document>. The ouput should be in a JSON string
where each key represents the role name as provided in the <event_roles> and its corresponding value should be a
list of contiguous text spans from the <report_document> that are valid for that role. 
Note that if no text span is found for a role, the value should be an empty list. 
Your text spans should strictly come from the <report_document>. DO NOT use spans from Event Definition or Roles sections.

2. Employer: The person (or institution) that takes on an <fen>Employee</fen>, giving them  <fen>Compensation</fen> in return for the performance of an assigned <fen>Task</fen>.

3. Task: The action that the <fen>Employee</fen> is taken on by the <fen>Employer</fen> to do.

4. Position: The label given to a particular type of employment.
Look, I wasn't hired <fex>as your waitress</fex>!
5. Field: The <fen>Field</fen> that the <fen>Employee</fen> is going to work in for their <fen>Employer</fen>.

6. Time: This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Guess who just got hired <fex>today</fex>!
7. Place: This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.

<event_type> Exchange </event_type>         <event_definition> Two parties, the Exchangers, each give and receive from the other Themes. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Exchanger_1: In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational
participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as
compared with <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Exchanger_1</fen> is generally
encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference
to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>. Thus
a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that
of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> or the group
of <fen>Exchangers</fen> as a whole.

2. Exchanger_2: In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> refers to the semantically
and grammatically less prominent group. It is generally encoded
within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with). Note that it
is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents.
For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were
plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.
The trade <fex>with Cuba</fex> went exactly as planned. 
3. Exchangers: In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Exchangers</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Exchangers</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Exchange frame, it is possible for the <fen>Exchangers</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.
<fex>Smithers and Kornfeldt</fex> traded Pez dispensers.
4. Theme_1: The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>.
 I tucked the pistol between my belt and tunic top (how I wish I had kept it, but I later swapped <fex>it</fex> with a Canadian for some cigarettes.
5. Theme_2: The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.
 The organization bought the property in 1999, then swapped it with the BLM <fex>for about 100 parcels in 10 counties ranging in size from one to 920 acres</fex>.
6. Themes: The items which change possession between the <fen>Exchangers</fen>.
They swapped <fex>guitars</fex>.
7. Time: This role identifies the time when the exchange takes place.

8. Place: This role identifies the place where the exchange occurs.

 </event_roles>        <report_document> <event> Traded </event> away : Chris Tarrant ( to Collingwood ) with pick # 45 for # 44 and # 56 Fremantle Dockers trade Chris Tarrant to Collingwood </report_document>

<event_type> Intentional_traversing </event_type>         <event_definition> A Self_mover intentionally moves in a Directionon a Path relative to landmark that is neither the Source nor the Goal of the overall motion. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Self_mover: This is a sentient being or a vehicle steered by a sentient being which moves.

2. Source: Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>.

<event_type> Revenge </event_type>         <event_definition> This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Avenger: The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.

Your job is to extract all the roles of the tagged Report <event> from the <report_document>. The ouput should be in a JSON string
where each key represents the role name as provided in the <event_roles> and its corresponding value should be a
list of contiguous text spans from the <report_document> that are valid for that role. 
Note that if no text span is found for a role, the value should be an empty list. 
Your text spans should strictly come from the <report_document>. DO NOT use spans from Event Definition or Roles sections.

<event_type> Hiring </event_type>         <event_definition> An Employer hires an Employee, promising the Employee a certain Compensation in exchange for the performance of a job. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Employee: The person whom the <fen>Employer</fen> takes on as an <fen>Employee</fen>, obligating them to perform some <fen>Task</fen> in order to receive <fen>Compensation</fen>.
<fex>I</fex> was just hired yesterday!
2. Employer: The person (or institution) that takes on an <fen>Employee</fen>, giving them  <fen>Compensation</fen> in return for the performance of an assigned <fen>Task</fen>.
Last month, <fex>IBM</fex> hired Mike Zisman to head up its storage software group.
3. Task: The action that the <fen>Employee</fen> is taken on by the <fen>Employer</fen> to do.
I was hired <fex>just to empty the trash cans</fex>.
4. Position: The label given to a particular type of employment.
Look, I wasn't hired <fex>as your waitress</fex>!
5. Field: The <fen>Field</fen> that the <fen>Employee</fen> is going to work in for their <fen>Employer</fen>.
It's not easy to get hired <fex>in academia</fex>.
6. Time: This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Guess who just got hired <fex>today</fex>!
7. Place: This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Actually, he hired me <fex>in a bordello</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> He was <event> hired </event> as a Research Scientist by Microsoft. </report_document>

<event_type> Clemency </event_type>         <event_definition> An Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an Offender who participated in an Crime. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Offender: The individual who is accused or convicted of a <fen>Crime</fen>.
Since 1976, <fex>225 death row inmates</fex> have been granted clemency for humanitarian
reasons. 
2. Crime: An action deemed criminal by law.
I never saw a legal case where a person was given clemency <fex>for murder</fex>.

4. Time: The time at which clemency is granted.
In addition to Ms.  White, 55, Mr.  Pataki granted clemency <fex>yesterday</fex> to three men serving long prison terms for offenses under the stern Rockefeller-era drug laws that mandate long sentences for some relatively low-level drug crimes.
5. Place: The location at which the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> grants clemency.

<event_type> Self_motion </event_type>         <event_definition> The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Self_mover: <fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
2. Source: <fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
3. Path: <fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
4. Goal: <fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
5. Area: <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
6. Direction: The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
7. Time: The time when the motion occurs.

8. Place: The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> Attacks on humans The hippo is considered to be extremely aggressive and has frequently been reported <event> charging </event> and attacking boats . </report_document>

2. Goods: The role Goods is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be illegally taken into our out of a country.

3. Source: The source is the location the goods occupy initially before change of location.

4. Path: The path refers to (a part of the) ground the Goods travel over or to a landmark the Goods travel by.

5. Goal: Goal is the location the Goods end up in.

6. Time: When the event occurs.

7. Place: Where the event takes place.

prompt.content:
You are a system that generates high quality document role annotations based on Framenet ontology.
The following inputs are given to you:
1. Event Type <event_type>: A Frame name from the FrameNet ontology (eg: Hiring, Arrest, etc.)
2. Event Definition <event_definition>: Definition of the event type along with an optional example. 
3. Roles <event_roles>: All roles (or participants) of the event type (or frame) followed with an optional example.
4. Report Document <report_document>: A report document with a tagged event '<event>' of the given event type.

Your job is to extract all the roles of the tagged Report <event> from the <report_document>. The ouput should be in a JSON string
where each key represents the role name as provided in the <event_roles> and its corresponding value should be a
list of contiguous text spans from the <report_document> that are valid for that role. 
Note that if no text span is found for a role, the value should be an empty list. 
Your text spans should strictly come from the <report_document>. DO NOT use spans from Event Definition or Roles sections.

<event_type> Hiring </event_type>         <event_definition> An Employer hires an Employee, promising the Employee a certain Compensation in exchange for the performance of a job. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Employee: The person whom the <fen>Employer</fen> takes on as an <fen>Employee</fen>, obligating them to perform some <fen>Task</fen> in order to receive <fen>Compensation</fen>.
<fex>I</fex> was just hired yesterday!
2. Employer: The person (or institution) that takes on an <fen>Employee</fen>, giving them  <fen>Compensation</fen> in return for the performance of an assigned <fen>Task</fen>.
Last month, <fex>IBM</fex> hired Mike Zisman to head up its storage software group.
3. Task: The action that the <fen>Employee</fen> is taken on by the <fen>Employer</fen> to do.
I was hired <fex>just to empty the trash cans</fex>.
4. Position: The label given to a particular type of employment.
Look, I wasn't hired <fex>as your waitress</fex>!
5. Field: The <fen>Field</fen> that the <fen>Employee</fen> is going to work in for their <fen>Employer</fen>.
It's not easy to get hired <fex>in academia</fex>.
6. Time: This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Guess who just got hired <fex>today</fex>!
7. Place: This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employer</fen> hires the <fen>Employee</fen>.
Actually, he hired me <fex>in a bordello</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> He was <event> hired </event> as a Research Scientist by Microsoft. </report_document>

{
  "Employee": ["He"],
  "Employer": ["Microsoft"],
  "Task": [],
  "Position": ["as a Research Scientist"],
  "Field": []
}

<event_type> Clemency </event_type>         <event_definition> An Executive_authority exercises their power to reduce or remove negative consequences for someone who has been labeled an Offender who participated in an Crime. </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Offender: The individual who is accused or convicted of a <fen>Crime</fen>.
Since 1976, <fex>225 death row inmates</fex> have been granted clemency for humanitarian
reasons. 
2. Crime: An action deemed criminal by law.
I never saw a legal case where a person was given clemency <fex>for murder</fex>.
3. Executive_authority: The constitutionally specified authority who has the power to grant clemency.
Mr. Papa was granted clemency for a drug conviction <fex>by Mr. Pataki</fex>, and released in 1997
4. Time: The time at which clemency is granted.
In addition to Ms.  White, 55, Mr.  Pataki granted clemency <fex>yesterday</fex> to three men serving long prison terms for offenses under the stern Rockefeller-era drug laws that mandate long sentences for some relatively low-level drug crimes.
5. Place: The location at which the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> grants clemency.
Apparently, no woman has ever been granted clemency <fex>there</fex>.
 </event_roles>        <report_document> In 2023, the governor granted <event> clemency </event> to the prisoner who had been wrongly convicted. </report_document>

  "Offender": ["the prisoner"],
  "Crime": [],
  "Executive_authority": ["The governor"],
  "Time": ["2023"],
  "Place": []
}

<event_type> Soaking </event_type>         <event_definition> In this frame, an Agent places the Theme in the Medium for an extended period of time, with the intent that the Theme will be affected by and absorb some of the Medium. ' </event_definition>        <event_roles> 1. Agent: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person performing the soaking.

2. Theme: The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.
 Ellen soaked <fex>the beans</fex> in the water for 30 seconds .
3. Medium: <fen>Medium</fen> is the substance in which the <fen>Theme</fen> is submerged.
Bobby soaked the potatoes <fex>in water</fex> overnight.
4. Time: The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> soaks the <fen>Theme</fen>.

5. Place: The <fen>Place</fen> where the submerging occurs.

 </event_roles>        <report_document> Chermoula is often made of a mixture of herbs , oil , lemon juice , pickled lemons , garlic , cumin , and salt . It may also include onion , fresh coriander , ground chili peppers , black pepper , or saffron . You are a system that generates high quality document role annotations based on Framenet ontology.
The following inputs are given to you:
1. Event Type <event_type>: A Frame name from the FrameNet ontology (eg: Hiring, Arrest, etc.)
2. Event Definition <event_definition>: Definition of the event type along with an optional example. 
3. Roles <event_roles>: All roles (or participants) of the event type (or frame) followed with an optional example.
4. Report Document <report_document>: A report document with a tagged event '<event>' of the given event type.

Your job is to extract all the roles of the tagged Report <event> from the <report_document>. The ouput should be in a JSON string
where each key represents the role name as provided in the <event_roles> and its corresponding value should be a
list of contiguous text spans from the <report_document> that are valid for that role. 
Note that if no text span is found for a role, the value should be an empty list. 
Your text spans should strictly come from the <report_document>. DO NOT use spans from Event Definition or Roles sections.
